quotes.topic_title: Deterministic to probabilistic marketing measurement shift
quotes.text: From 2010 to 2020, we had the golden years of deterministic matching where it was very easy to run an ad and understand with precision who installed the app.
quotes.speaker: Austin Hay
quotes.context: Sets the baseline of how attribution used to work and why today’s measurement environment is fundamentally different.

quotes.topic_title: Deterministic to probabilistic marketing measurement shift
quotes.text: You can't do that anymore.
quotes.speaker: Austin Hay
quotes.context: A blunt, memorable inflection point that forces a shift from deterministic attribution to probabilistic approaches.

quotes.topic_title: Deterministic to probabilistic marketing measurement shift
quotes.text: And so I am paying a lot of attention to how marketers make decisions with probabilistic data because most of the work that I'm doing now is actually saying, well, given that we don't have determinist data about a per certain audience or where somebody came from, how can I find other information that will create a model for 30% of the population and we can use that to extrapolate to a hundred.
quotes.speaker: Austin Hay
quotes.context: Provides a practical measurement methodology: build models on partial observability (e.g., 30%) and extrapolate to the full population.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In our conversation, Austin explains what exactly is MarTech, how it fits into your growth organization when you need to hire a MarTech person and what to look for plus his favorite interview questions.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Sets up practical, practitioner-focused guidance on where MarTech belongs in an org and how to hire for it.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: He's advised companies like Notion, Airbnb, Walmart, Postmates, Robinhood, even Pete's Coffee and Mars on their MarTech strategy and tactics.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Provides concrete examples of the breadth of companies applying MarTech strategy, signaling cross-industry relevance.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Also, his favorite tools, frameworks, team structures, and emerging platforms that he's most excited about.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights that the episode will cover reusable frameworks and organizational patterns, not just tool lists.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Customers always seem to want to give you their data in the messiest possible CSV file.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A memorable, practical observation about real-world data ingestion challenges that teams should plan for.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Six months later, you're fixing yet another date conversion edge case bug.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Captures the long-tail maintenance cost of building importers, a cautionary point for product and engineering teams.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Customers always seem to want to give you their data in the messiest possible CSV file.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (OneSchema)
quotes.context: Highlights a practical reality of B2B onboarding: you must design for messy, real-world customer data rather than ideal inputs.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: And building a spreadsheet importer becomes a never ending sync for your engineering and support resources.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (OneSchema)
quotes.context: Warns that DIY CSV importers can turn into ongoing operational drag, informing build-vs-buy decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Six months later, you're fixing yet another date conversion edge case bug.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (OneSchema)
quotes.context: A concrete example of how edge cases accumulate over time, making maintenance costs easy to underestimate.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Customers get frustrated by useless messages like error on line 53 and never end up getting started with your product.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (OneSchema)
quotes.context: Connects poor error UX directly to activation failure, emphasizing that onboarding friction can prevent product adoption entirely.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Powered by first party behavioral data instead of third party cookies.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Mixpanel)
quotes.context: Points to a durable analytics approach as cookie-based tracking declines, guiding teams toward first-party instrumentation.

quotes.topic_title: What MarTech is and what it does
quotes.text: Because marketing technology is like this very amorphous, cross-functional discipline that lives at the crossroads of product and growth and engineering and marketing.
quotes.speaker: Austin Hay
quotes.context: Defines MarTech as an inherently cross-functional discipline, clarifying where it sits in an org and why it often feels hard to pin down.

quotes.topic_title: What MarTech is and what it does
quotes.text: And I think really the way to think about marketing technology is it's a product manager whose specific role and focus is the system or the third party or first party platform because marketing technology can mean a collection of third party tools, which is a lot of people think, but as a company scales and grows actually it could include a collection of first party homegrown solutions that you build yourself with or in addition to third party.
quotes.speaker: Austin Hay
quotes.context: Offers a practical mental model—MarTech as “PM for systems/platforms”—and expands the scope beyond just buying tools to also building internal platforms as you scale.

quotes.topic_title: What MarTech is and what it does
quotes.text: So, I like to think about marketing technology more as one piece is people and process and the other is the system and the platform.
quotes.speaker: Austin Hay
quotes.context: Provides a simple two-part framework practitioners can use to assess MarTech gaps: org/process vs. tooling/platform.

quotes.topic_title: What MarTech is and what it does
quotes.text: And then you asked this other question around what exactly the role of somebody in MarTech, and maybe we'll talk about this a little later, but it's such a function of the size and the stage of the company that you're at.
quotes.speaker: Austin Hay
quotes.context: Highlights that MarTech responsibilities should be designed around company stage, preventing overbuilding the function too early or underinvesting too late.

quotes.topic_title: What MarTech is and what it does
quotes.text: A small startup for example, when I was working with Siqi, we were just talking about this at Runway, there was no such thing as MarTech. There was me and Tanner and Siqi standing up tools and using them because you just have to use the tools to get the job done.
quotes.speaker: Austin Hay
quotes.context: A concrete example showing that early-stage MarTech is often an ad-hoc responsibility rather than a formal function, guiding how teams should staff and prioritize.

quotes.topic_title: MarTech vs growth roles and when it emerges
quotes.text: But what I would say is as a company grows and scales, it moves from being a community or village driven aspect of your products to being something that's centrally owned.
quotes.speaker: Austin Hay
quotes.context: A clear mental model for how MarTech ownership evolves from shared responsibility to centralized function as complexity increases.

quotes.topic_title: MarTech vs growth roles and when it emerges
quotes.text: As you cross a hundred to 200 people, somebody has to be responsible for knowing how data flows through tools, how it's worked, what's the schema.
quotes.speaker: Austin Hay
quotes.context: A practical trigger point for when to create a dedicated MarTech/systems owner focused on data flow and tooling architecture.

quotes.topic_title: MarTech vs growth roles and when it emerges
quotes.text: And so usually around I would call it a hundred to 150 people is the critical mass where you can't just have a village approach to systems and tools much like in the IT org, if it was a village approach to SSO businesses would be in a lot of danger.
quotes.speaker: Austin Hay
quotes.context: A specific headcount benchmark plus an analogy (SSO) that makes the risk of decentralized tool ownership feel concrete.

quotes.topic_title: MarTech vs growth roles and when it emerges
quotes.text: In a B2C business, your user funnel is actually really simple acquiring users and you're getting them into your product and then product is taking them over. There's no additional CRM, so usually your CDP is the source of truth and that's where you might actually see marketing technology fit in with growth a lot more.
quotes.speaker: Austin Hay
quotes.context: A useful B2C vs B2B heuristic for where MarTech should sit organizationally and what becomes the system of record.

quotes.topic_title: MarTech vs growth roles and when it emerges
quotes.text: Just some examples like at Postmates, I worked for them for a long time as a consultant. Marketing technology was just part of growth.
quotes.speaker: Austin Hay
quotes.context: A concrete example showing that at some companies MarTech can live inside growth rather than as a standalone function.

quotes.topic_title: Signals you need a MarTech hire
quotes.text: And I have this adage I always say, which is tools are just meant to solve problems.
quotes.speaker: Austin Hay
quotes.context: A simple mental model for evaluating MarTech work: start from the problem, not the tool.

quotes.topic_title: Signals you need a MarTech hire
quotes.text: And everybody thinks that marketing technology is just the third party tools, but actually it's designing, architecting and building that stuff on top of your third party tools.
quotes.speaker: Austin Hay
quotes.context: Reframes MarTech as systems design and custom architecture, not just tool procurement.

quotes.topic_title: Signals you need a MarTech hire
quotes.text: That's how you actually have a lot of velocity is thinking about not just build versus buy. It's build and buy now. So, you buy the tool to get 90% of the way there and then you build the cool thing on top with the other 10%.
quotes.speaker: Austin Hay
quotes.context: A practical methodology for scaling faster: combine off-the-shelf tools with targeted custom work.

quotes.topic_title: Signals you need a MarTech hire
quotes.text: The one really unsexy part of it, which I tend to love because it's really high leverage is the contract part.
quotes.speaker: Austin Hay
quotes.context: Highlights a high-impact but overlooked MarTech responsibility: managing vendor terms, costs, and risk.

quotes.topic_title: Signals you need a MarTech hire
quotes.text: Yeah, efficiency and pain. I would say pain drives people more.
quotes.speaker: Austin Hay
quotes.context: A hiring signal heuristic: prioritize MarTech hires when operational pain blocks progress, not just when seeking efficiency.

quotes.topic_title: Where MarTech should sit in the org
quotes.text: So, first with B2C and really maybe a simpler version of that is centralized versus decentralized. So, we have B2C, B2B, centralized, decentralized.
quotes.speaker: Austin Hay
quotes.context: He introduces a simple 2x2 mental model for deciding where MarTech should sit based on company type and org design.

quotes.topic_title: Where MarTech should sit in the org
quotes.text: Most of the time your tools, your marketing tools are intended to help the growth team. The growth team has a job to be done, which is to spur user growth and tools are just meant to solve the problem. So, marketing technology's job is to serve the growth team.
quotes.speaker: Austin Hay
quotes.context: A clear stakeholder-first principle for B2C: place MarTech where it best serves the growth mandate.

quotes.topic_title: Where MarTech should sit in the org
quotes.text: I generally don't see that working very well just because as you add more operational people, it just creates more systems.
quotes.speaker: Austin Hay
quotes.context: A counterintuitive warning that decentralizing ops/MarTech often increases complexity rather than improving execution.

quotes.topic_title: Where MarTech should sit in the org
quotes.text: We started centralized with the Rev ops group, we decentralized it and put marketing technology into the CMO org and now we're rolling it back into the revenue operations org Largely has to do with who is our customer?
quotes.speaker: Austin Hay
quotes.context: A concrete example from Ramp showing org placement can (and should) change as the primary customer and needs shift.

quotes.topic_title: Where MarTech should sit in the org
quotes.text: And yeah, I would just say especially on B2B, for people out there listening, there is no right answer.
quotes.speaker: Austin Hay
quotes.context: He emphasizes that B2B/B2B2C MarTech placement is inherently context-dependent, pushing against one-size-fits-all org charts.

quotes.topic_title: IC nature of MarTech and cross-functional influence
quotes.text: I think all marketing technologists at some level are ICs.
quotes.speaker: Austin Hay
quotes.context: Reframes MarTech leadership as inherently hands-on, not purely managerial.

quotes.topic_title: IC nature of MarTech and cross-functional influence
quotes.text: So, what I would say is more important to look for than how many people has this person managed is how well can they manage upward, laterally and downward because they're going to have to go talk to the head of rev ops if they want to change something in Salesforce, they're going to have to talk to the VP of product if they want to make a big platform change that touches something else.
quotes.speaker: Austin Hay
quotes.context: Gives a practical hiring/assessment criterion: cross-functional influence beats headcount managed in MarTech roles.

quotes.topic_title: IC nature of MarTech and cross-functional influence
quotes.text: I almost view them like a true quarterback every [inaudible 00:19:41] says people are quarterbacks. But really marketing technology because it lives between so many departments, it plays that role of having to call plays and pull on different departments.
quotes.speaker: Austin Hay
quotes.context: Offers a memorable mental model for the MarTech function as a cross-department “quarterback.”

quotes.topic_title: IC nature of MarTech and cross-functional influence
quotes.text: Totally. Yeah. It's a game of persuasion and salesmanship.
quotes.speaker: Austin Hay
quotes.context: Highlights that MarTech leverage often comes from persuasion rather than direct ownership of resources.

quotes.topic_title: IC nature of MarTech and cross-functional influence
quotes.text: I'll just give you one example. Like lots of big companies I talked to have two CDPs or two attribution tools and it's like there's the cost problem. How do we get rid of this secondary tool to reduce the cost? Maybe it's a million dollars, but there's also the complexity and decision-making problem.
quotes.speaker: Austin Hay
quotes.context: Concrete example of stack duplication showing the dual impact: hard cost plus decision-making drag.

quotes.topic_title: Day-to-day MarTech work and future-proofing systems
quotes.text: So, I think a big part of the role is designing systems that are automated to handle that stuff because ideally you don't want to be sitting around in your computer all day clicking one conductor request to approve permissions.
quotes.speaker: Austin Hay
quotes.context: Highlights a leverage-focused MarTech principle: automate repetitive governance/permission workflows instead of doing manual approvals.

quotes.topic_title: Day-to-day MarTech work and future-proofing systems
quotes.text: So, it's about how do we design a system and create a vision and persuade people about what our system technology can look like over the course of one to two years, the time span that I usually look at.
quotes.speaker: Austin Hay
quotes.context: Provides a practical planning horizon (1–2 years) and frames MarTech as vision-setting plus stakeholder persuasion, not just tool admin.

quotes.topic_title: Day-to-day MarTech work and future-proofing systems
quotes.text: Can we build a financial model to show how much it's going to cost us both in terms of operational efficiency and actual real fixed and variable costs to end up in that state?
quotes.speaker: Austin Hay
quotes.context: Recommends using a cost model (efficiency + fixed/variable costs) to justify MarTech transformations and engineering investment.

quotes.topic_title: Day-to-day MarTech work and future-proofing systems
quotes.text: I would say the big thing that people forget in an early stage of a company's lifetime is that the company will outlast you, hopefully.
quotes.speaker: Austin Hay
quotes.context: A counterweight to short-term growth tactics: optimize for stewardship because systems persist beyond any individual owner.

quotes.topic_title: Day-to-day MarTech work and future-proofing systems
quotes.text: Some examples are like if it's $2,000 to get SSO and two days to set it up and that prevents you from having a security problem where somebody downloads all your users, it seems like a great investment.
quotes.speaker: Austin Hay
quotes.context: Concrete example with time/cost numbers showing how small upfront investments (SSO) can prevent major security and operational risk later.

quotes.topic_title: Supporting paid growth and funnel data activation
quotes.text: We didn't talk about this in the beginning, but there's marketing technology and marketing operations.
quotes.speaker: Austin Hay
quotes.context: Introduces a useful distinction practitioners can use to clarify roles, hiring, and ownership across MarTech vs. MarOps.

quotes.topic_title: Supporting paid growth and funnel data activation
quotes.text: So, in my mind when we talk about marketing technology, I'm really thinking it as an engineering based role
quotes.speaker: Austin Hay
quotes.context: Defines MarTech as fundamentally engineering-driven, which helps teams set expectations for skills, scope, and deliverables.

quotes.topic_title: Supporting paid growth and funnel data activation
quotes.text: Well, I think the most superhuman user acquisition people out there are engineers and they don't need a marketing technologist because they set up the tool themself.
quotes.speaker: Austin Hay
quotes.context: Counterintuitive observation that the best paid growth operators often eliminate the need for a separate MarTech partner by being technical themselves.

quotes.topic_title: Supporting paid growth and funnel data activation
quotes.text: As you scale, you divide responsibility and you'll see you'll have the person who's responsible for bidding and acquiring users and paying down those campaign costs. Then you have the person who's in charge of how does it all work? How do we get this thing to actually run?
quotes.speaker: Austin Hay
quotes.context: Actionable scaling model for splitting paid growth execution from the technical systems work required to run and measure it.

quotes.topic_title: Supporting paid growth and funnel data activation
quotes.text: We're trying to get top of funnel data all the way down to the bottom of the funnel and tie it with opportunity data so we could send that back to the ad network so that rather than optimizing your campaign off of when a user clicks a button on the website, you're actually optimizing it off of did the opportunity occur and what was the kind of ideal value for that opportunity?
quotes.speaker: Austin Hay
quotes.context: Concrete example of advanced funnel data activation: feeding downstream opportunity/value signals back to ad platforms to improve optimization.

quotes.topic_title: How MarTech should be goaled and measured
quotes.text: So, if user acquisition has, I mean we do, we have a growth goal and we have a CAC goal at Ramp. So, my goals are tied to them, so I'm going to help make sure that that is achieved, but then there's also a cost and efficiency goal that I internally think is valuable.
quotes.speaker: Austin Hay
quotes.context: A practical goaling model: align MarTech to core growth/CAC outcomes while also owning internal efficiency targets.

quotes.topic_title: How MarTech should be goaled and measured
quotes.text: Have I set us up for success so that as we grow, our cost per user or cost per seat comes down and how much more efficient are we because of that?
quotes.speaker: Austin Hay
quotes.context: A concrete efficiency metric MarTech leaders can track over time: tooling cost per user/seat should decrease with scale.

quotes.topic_title: How MarTech should be goaled and measured
quotes.text: The ideal world is that you actually are growing as a business making more money, hiring more people, acquiring more users, and your total cost of tooling per person goes down. That's like the dream.
quotes.speaker: Austin Hay
quotes.context: A memorable north-star benchmark that reframes MarTech success as scaling capability while lowering per-person tooling cost.

quotes.topic_title: How MarTech should be goaled and measured
quotes.text: And so there'll be a big six-month initiative to say, we just got to switch. That's the goal. We have to safely get off this small tool to a much bigger, more complex tool that's going to cost us more. It's a lot more complex, but we need to do it without losing money.
quotes.speaker: Austin Hay
quotes.context: A specific example of a common MarTech transformation: migrating email platforms as you outgrow early tools, with a clear constraint (no revenue loss).

quotes.topic_title: Recommended B2C stack evolution: CDPs to reverse ETL
quotes.text: The thing about it though that I think really changed around 2020 is that the cost of ownership of warehousing became much cheaper.
quotes.speaker: Austin Hay
quotes.context: Highlights the key inflection point that enabled the shift from CDP-centered stacks to warehouse-first architectures.

quotes.topic_title: Recommended B2C stack evolution: CDPs to reverse ETL
quotes.text: I think that's a great move if you do not have a lot of engineering resources because you're not spending a ton of time and energy on a warehouse and all the modeling that comes with it, you're just spending time to implement one SDK.
quotes.speaker: Austin Hay
quotes.context: Gives a practical decision rule for when a traditional CDP-first approach is the right tradeoff.

quotes.topic_title: Recommended B2C stack evolution: CDPs to reverse ETL
quotes.text: If you are an advanced engineering culture and you are cutting edge and you're going to do a bunch of modeling in DBT and you already have Snowflake, you should move towards a model of using a reverse ETL.
quotes.speaker: Austin Hay
quotes.context: Provides a clear heuristic for when to adopt reverse ETL/warehouse-first activation based on org capability and tooling.

quotes.topic_title: Recommended B2C stack evolution: CDPs to reverse ETL
quotes.text: Where do you choose? And I would say a lot of businesses get in trouble when they don't have a methodology or a system for how and when to move data from one place to the other, so they just do it haphazardly, right?
quotes.speaker: Austin Hay
quotes.context: Warns that multiple data-movement paths create governance risk unless you define explicit rules for routing data.

quotes.topic_title: Recommended B2C stack evolution: CDPs to reverse ETL
quotes.text: And the key in systems management is you want to design a process for doing it some type of waterfall or mental model for when it makes sense to move data directly from Amplitude, which is the ingestion point of your data stream or from the warehouse where you can model it and make it better.
quotes.speaker: Austin Hay
quotes.context: Introduces a concrete mental model (“waterfall”) for deciding whether to activate data from the ingestion layer vs. the modeled warehouse.

quotes.topic_title: B2B and B2B2C stack complexity and CRM interplay
quotes.text: And for the most part, that's how B2B still exists today as you have Salesforce and then the whole world and the universe revolves around Salesforce.
quotes.speaker: Austin Hay
quotes.context: A crisp mental model for Salesforce-centric B2B stacks that helps practitioners reason about architecture and tool selection.

quotes.topic_title: B2B and B2B2C stack complexity and CRM interplay
quotes.text: you now have this whole rise of B2B2C, which takes all the complexity of the top of funnel user acquisition system and stuffs it right alongside your CRM and how you build an elegant system there in that space, I think is one of the most complicated and intricate pieces of being a MarTech person today.
quotes.speaker: Austin Hay
quotes.context: Frames B2B2C as a fundamentally harder systems-design problem by combining B2C acquisition complexity with CRM requirements.

quotes.topic_title: B2B and B2B2C stack complexity and CRM interplay
quotes.text: Like all these B2C tools were designed with two objects, a user and an event.
quotes.speaker: Austin Hay
quotes.context: A useful abstraction for diagnosing why B2C tooling often breaks down when you need account/entity mapping in B2B2C.

quotes.topic_title: B2B and B2B2C stack complexity and CRM interplay
quotes.text: B2B2C is fascinating because you have all the complexity at the top, but then how and when do you tie a user to a company or some type of entity object, and what tools do you need to do that and where do they live in the system?
quotes.speaker: Austin Hay
quotes.context: Highlights the core identity/entity-resolution decision practitioners must make (and where it should live) to avoid downstream data chaos.

quotes.topic_title: B2B and B2B2C stack complexity and CRM interplay
quotes.text: Both are CRMs, both have the ability to track users and companies, neither are CDPs. And how you actually map the data from HubSpot to Salesforce kind of determines how much hell you're in, and there's really no good solution.
quotes.speaker: Austin Hay
quotes.context: A concrete example and warning that running multiple CRMs creates unavoidable tradeoffs, with mapping choices driving operational pain.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: You might be building an incredible AI product, but if you're using the same data sets as your competitors to train your models, you don't have much of an advantage.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a practical differentiation lever for AI products: proprietary or fresher data can be a defensible advantage.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Brave Search is the fastest growing search engine since Bing, and it's 100% independent from the big tech companies.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Provides a concrete positioning/data point about Brave Search’s growth and independence as an alternative search index provider.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: If you're building products with search capabilities, you're probably experiencing soaring API costs or lack of viable global alternatives to Bing or Google.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Names two common operational constraints teams can plan around when shipping search features: cost and vendor concentration risk.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: AI devs will particularly benefit from data containing thorough coverage of recent events.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Actionable guidance on what kind of data to prioritize for AI applications: recency and coverage of current events.

quotes.topic_title: Attribution approaches: MMM vs MTA foundations
quotes.text: MTA and MMM though are both underpinned by how you collect data.
quotes.speaker: Austin Hay
quotes.context: Reframes attribution method debates as downstream of data collection quality, guiding teams to prioritize instrumentation first.

quotes.topic_title: Attribution approaches: MMM vs MTA foundations
quotes.text: They're both informed by the user object and the event objects that you collect on your website or your application that then lead to the data that data scientists use for MTA and MMM.
quotes.speaker: Austin Hay
quotes.context: Provides a concrete mental model (user + event objects) for what must exist in the data pipeline to enable MMM/MTA.

quotes.topic_title: Attribution approaches: MMM vs MTA foundations
quotes.text: And one of the most discreet things you can do for MTA, because I get this question all the time around, hey, do we need MTA?
quotes.speaker: Austin Hay
quotes.context: Highlights a common practitioner decision point and sets up a practical approach to preparing for attribution needs.

quotes.topic_title: Attribution approaches: MMM vs MTA foundations
quotes.text: And there's actually really, I can send you this guide, but there's six or seven things you can do to basically futureproof yourself from needing either one.
quotes.speaker: Austin Hay
quotes.context: Counterintuitively suggests you can reduce dependence on complex attribution models by doing foundational setup work early.

quotes.topic_title: Attribution approaches: MMM vs MTA foundations
quotes.text: So, an example, would this be like if I went to Lenny's Newsletter from a Google ad and that's all he has? That would be my first touch and my last touch.
quotes.speaker: Austin Hay
quotes.context: Gives a simple, memorable example that clarifies first-touch vs last-touch attribution in real terms.
